Download and distribute optional files; download newly published sites; keep old sites updated; keep ZeroNet updated and running even when you're not using it.

The hdd space and bandwith you contribute go directly into keeping the network healthy and its content accessible to others.

If an individual can misuse your service in a certain way, you must operate under the assumption that someone eventually will.
It is irresponsible to not account for this when you are developing code, or a service, or an uncensorable distributed network.

As individuals who access other people's services and view content others post, we also are responsible to ourselves to ensure we remain safe and are not harmed while we are browsing and stumble across something.

It is not some anonymous admin's responsibility to protect us. We have to be smart enough to take care of ourselves and to be mindful of what kinds of things we are seeding to other machines and what kinds of things have been written to files on our hard drives.

If the idea that ZeroNet can be used to host and distribute certain kinds of content upsets you, and you wish the ZeroNet community, nofish, or the offending site administrators would do something to combat this, it might be better for you to remove this software from your computer and step outside.

The ZeroNet community DOES, however, have a responsibility to itself to educate everyone, especially new users, how the network functions. For starters, it is necessary for them to understand how downloading and seeding files work, as well as how to delete and blacklist sites they do not wish to help distribute. You can't browse safely if you do not have a basic understanding of how the network works.

If changes need to be made to the built in tools in ZeroNet to enable everyone to stay safe, that is a conversation which ZeroNet needs to take up with the developer.

Millchan now features a user-created CP board. The dev explains his reasoning in pic attached why he thinks that should not be a problem for his users. I find it inadequate, so I have added Millchan to my blacklist, and I encourage others do the same so that they do not find themselves on the wrong side of the law.

I'm quite frustrated by this. I'm a strong proponent of free speech, and have very strong feelings against censorship, but we all live in societies where crossing certain lines can lead to having you stripped of all of your freedoms. I don't like it, and as a member of society I would like to see that changed. But it is a fact of the world we live in. This user-created board has the capability of putting Millchan users in legal jeopardy.

The Millchan admin is free to run his site the way he likes. I don't desire to censor or stifle him, were I to even have that power. It is his decision, and I know he has strong beliefs in what he is doing. However, I feel compelled to warn others of the risks that now run by accessing his site, though perhaps others find the solutions he offers adequate for staying safe from inadvertently participating in illegal activity. I must say that I do not.

And if I'm overreacting, or perhaps what he says in his post is quite valid and there is no risk of harm, I would be quite happy to be convinced of my wrongness so that I may return to the chan that I was beginning to grow fond of.

[EulerFinder](/13eFkhbXXQcJqd729zRLL9tMxxhz9d4UA6/) appears to be the most actively updated search engine on ZeroNet. Having your zite listed on [0list](/186THqMWuptrZxq1rxzpguAivK3Bs6z84o/) is enough to get listed on there.

It should be noted however that EulerFinder uses your cpu to mine bitcoins. If you wish to avoid this, you should use uMatrix or NoScript + Request Policy to avoid malicious 3rd party content including javascript. 3rd party sites on the web have no business on my browser while I'm using ZeroNet anyway.

I'm not actually sure what it takes to get listed on a few of the other search engines though, apart from directly contacting the owner, if the site is even still operational.

it appears a lot of search engines were relying on the bit.surf zeronet proxy to acquire new zite listings but that proxy is no longer operational and those search engines no longer accumulate new zites. tsk tsk, depending on non-permanent, censorable resources outside of zeronet was not the way to go.

it's definitely more sensible and futureproof to pull new zites from listings such as 0list, ZeroSites, etcetera. but I suppose the downside is after you die your service will keep adding links which might violate your TOS. but is having an uncensored search engine such a bad thing?

zite idea: a zite with which users can develop and publish twine stories, and where other users can play these published stories.

the user would type up their twine story on the zite (bonus points if the stories are saved on the zite and encrypted so only the author can view and edit the story while it is still a WIP).

once they finish, they can hit "publish" to have their completed twine featured on the zite. users visiting the zite can play these twine games.

there are probably feasibility or security concerns with this since the zite is effectively hosting user submitted .html documents. there might be additional feasibility concerns if twine authors wanted their stories to have graphics or sound.

so [KxoVid](/14c5LUN73J7KKMznp9LvZWkxpZFWgE1sDz/) is pretty neat. a while back people were aching for "Youtube on ZeroNet". although we've had KopyKate for a while, i feel that KxoVid already outshines it. all it's really lacking is videos to watch.

for the time being it only accepts the new KxoID, so you'll want to [go over to his site](/1GTVetvjTEriCMzKzWSP9FahYoMPy6BG1P/), set up the PeerMessage plugin, and register one.

when you upload a video, you choose which hub the data is uploaded to. all of the current hubs are structured as different categories (eg. News/Politics, Animation, Documentaries, etc). any user who clicks on one of those hubs will recieve a list of all the videos uploaded to it, which will be useful for finding new vids.

there appears to be a feature that allows you to create playlists on your channel. i don't think any other video site on ZN has this.

the design needs worked on, and there's no video thumbnails yet, although i believe @Krixano: is working on both of these things. all in all, this appears to be a worthy successor to KopyKate, and it'll be cool to watch it grow.

you know what else is really cool? [sakana.bit](/sakana.bit/)
it's a frontend for ZeroMe modeled after Mastadon.

the extended circle view is great. it shows not only posts of the people you follow, but the people they follow too. so it opens the network up a little bit, a nice middle ground between "Followed users" and "Everyone". i just used it to follow someone i hadn't noticed before among the tide of all the global posts.

there's two really good live chats on ZN that are seldom used.

if you want to know when someone's said something new you can subscribe to all new messages on your Hello page for either zite.

[0Play Game Center](/1Ag6xidDHiPgWoDKhfSx4xFQr6WC3NqxZg/):
simply click "Following" at the top right.
edit: this ~~supports~~ **requires** the [PeerMessage plugin](/1GTVetvjTEriCMzKzWSP9FahYoMPy6BG1P/?/plugins), which means it features actual real-time chat and you don't need to wait 30 seconds to send a new message.

[ThunderWave](/thunderwave.bit/):
click the dropdown menu at the top right, and go to settings. where it says "Notifications in ZeroHello-Feed", you can set it to subscribe to "All Messages"

# **UN Proposal to Ban Fictional Works as "Child Pornography"**

The United Nations is asking for feedback on a [new set of proposals](https://www.ohchr.org/EN/HRBodies/CRC/Pages/DraftGuidelinesOPs.aspx) for the international community to rally against child prostitution, the sale of children, and child pornography.

## Sounds great, right?

But a close look at their definition of child pornography reveals that this extends a little bit beyond that. [Drawings, cartoons, written stories, sculptures, and other forms of fictional works](https://www.oneangrygamer.net/2019/02/u-n-proposes-initiative-to-ban-loli-shota-and-underage-drawings-and-cartoons/77229/amp/) are also tucked in under the guise of "child pornography".

A progressive new CSA (child sexual abuse) prevention organization, Prostasia Foundation, recently did [an excellent writeup](https://prostasia.org/blog/experts-to-united-nations-hentai-ban-would-be-a-mistake/) on this UN proposal.

## **This ban may be counterproductive at preventing CSA**

There is no evidence that banning fictitious works has this effect. [Some experts](http://www.sexologytoday.org/2017/02/canada-and-australia-now-have-both.html) do [believe](https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2016/01/can-child-dolls-keep-pedophiles-from-offending/423324/) bans, such as what the UN guidelines as written seek to ban, could actually lead to a rise in CSA.

With zero evidence that banning these things helps children, and with experts fearing that bans like this could put children in jeopardy, it is absolutely premature to implement such a ban until the necessary research has been conducted.

there is no evidence that banning fictitious works has any impact on reducing CSA (child sexual abuse). [some](http://www.sexologytoday.org/2017/02/canada-and-australia-now-have-both.html) [experts](https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2016/01/can-child-dolls-keep-pedophiles-from-offending/423324/) believe that bans on the types of things these UN guidelines seek to ban will actually lead to a rise in CSA.

## **This ban is a gross violation of freedom of speech and expression**

This will have chilling effects.

Most anime, which frequently features high school aged characters, will fall under fire for having "underage" characters depicted. Novels, comics, fanfiction, art, fanart, sculptures, and other creative works featuring characters that "appear underage" (aka under 18) will similarly be harmed by the implementation of these international guidelines.

Websites operating in countries that follow these UN guidelines may find themselves reluctant to support anime or artist communities, since their duty to police content will become even more strict. We have seen the chilling effects on speech that puritan policies such as this have (see: Reddit's [harsh subreddit bans](https://piunikaweb.com/2019/02/12/reddit-facing-massive-public-outcry-after-alleged-loli-crackdown/), Steam's [removal of adult games featuring high school aged girls](https://nichegamer.com/2018/12/06/all-ages-modified-vn-hello-good-bye-banned-on-steam/)).

## **We need to tell the UN that fictional children are not children**

Although the UN's intentions are surely noble, equating artwork to child pornography is a farce which undermines the very concept of harm that CP creation and dissemination has on children, and a slap in the face to survivors of childhood sexual abuse, whose very real depictions of abuse and trauma continue to circulate throughout the internet.

Anyone who would like to join me in presenting opposition to parts of the UN's proposal can do so. They are accepting comments by email. **Comments must be submitted by 31 March 2019.**

* You can [email the UN](crc@ohchr.org) directly, following their [guidelines on submissions](https://www.ohchr.org/EN/HRBodies/CRC/Pages/DraftGuidelinesOPs.aspx).
* Prostasia has created a [form to submit a pre-written email](https://prostasia.org/campaign/art-not-csem/) signed in your name.

**If you are an active member in anime or artist communities, please help spread the word about this issue. Together, we can convey to the UN and the international community why this new attack on free speech will not be tolerated.**
